text:
Wonderful either cold or warm! I reduced the sugar for the topping to 1/4 cup to give it a stronger cinnamon flavor, and I liked it that way. I also used Neufchatel cheese that is labeled to have "1/3 less fat than cream cheese" and you couldn't taste a difference. I did not use the honey topping because I thought it would be too sweet. I actually served this for breakfast! Believe it or not, it makes a wonderful breakfast treat - great with bacon/sausage and a fruit salad! When I serve this for dessert (and I'm sure I will!!) I will try the honey on the top, but it's wonderful without, too.

text:
Wonderful dessert for our Supper Club. Hubby couldn't attend, so he got the leftovers today - not a big dessert guy, so when he tried it and I got a "Wow..." out of him - I was floored! Then he subtly asked, "So there was only that one piece left...?" (thankfully for him, a couple more are left.) Used the extra large crescent rolls, little less sugar in the middle, and broiled the top for a couple of minutes to brown it nicely. Served cold (wasn't sure if I should - thanks for RExch opinions) - so simple, easy ingredients (used reg vanilla b/c had it onhand, omitted honey) so good, and feeds a lot!

text:
First I have to say this was WONDERFUL!! Reminded me alot of Oooey Gooey Cake...Just alot easier and so tastey!! Everyone at the party wanted the recipe and I mean everyone! Will definately make during the holidays..  I cooked the crust for a few minutes to heat up and allow the cream cheese layer to spread easier.  Also did small dollups of cream cheese all over the crust otherwise it would be to hard to spread.  Did same with the butter on the top crust...Didn't roll out crust just pressed the seems together too.  And it was easy and looked just fine after cooking...Honey made a big different for those who wanted honey...gave it an extra little something!!  Let everyone put on the honey themselves...Thank you CandelB for such a wonderful recipe!!!

stephanja

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you are looking for something easy that most everyone will like and will impress your guests, this is it! It is original and delicious! A definite favorite. I already love cheesecake, but this offers a different  twist that still offers the great cream cheese flavor. I made two batches two separate ways after reading other reviews on here..some people suggested melting the butter and pouring it on top and then sprinkling cinn./sug....i did that and it was okay, hardly any different from the original way of the recipe..but i would say i like the original way best. But for ease and time sake I think I will probably contnue to melt the butter because the difference is so unnoticeable..and it is easier to get the butter mix even that way. Also I ate the first whole batch warm or room temp and it was awesome..but the consistency was definately better chilled. When warm the cream cheese separates some from the crescent. Either way honestly takes great. I also TOTALLY forgot about the honey..I will try it next time but it is great without it. I also thought it was amusing that everyone thought it was "Mexican" and sopapillas don't even exist in the hispanic culture lol (at least thats what my native-Guadalajara husband tells me). But anyone will love this dish, that is for SURE!

text:
SO easy and SO good.  I made this for the first time and it was so easy to make. I cut back on the sugar in the mixture and on top by 1/4 a cup and it was so good. I don't think you need to roll out the crescent rolls at all. Just open the cans and place the pastry in the bottom of the dish and smush the dots together. I cooked it for about 45 minutes and it was yummy. I also didn't "dot" the butter and cinnamon mixture. I smoothed it out all over the whole pan and drizzled honey when it was cooling. I prefer these cold as well.

text:
Just as all the other reviewers have said "this is delicious." I followed the ingredients to a T and everything came out perfect! I don't enjoy reading reviews when the ingredients and preparaton are altered and then the recipe is given a poor rating--I hope this suggestion doesn't fall into that category--as other viewers have written there is no need to roll out the crescent dough-just carefully press the perforations together after putting the dough in the prepared pan: both on the bottom and top crust-saves time and looks great!

THIS IS SO GOOD!  I couldn't find mexican vanilla, so i used the normal stuff and other than that, followed the directions to a T.  I was worried when I took it out of the oven, it was pretty and brown and fluffy but the butter/sugar mix on top had pooled in places and seemed too wet like maybe I should put it back in for a few minutes...but I decided not to and a few minutes later, I look at it and the fluffy brown pastry on top had sunken quite a bit and then I REALLY worried that I should have cooked it longer (hubby even laughed and asked if my cheesecake was supposed to look like that!)....but by the time that it had cooled completely, it was delicious and I wouldn't do anything differently next time.

text:
I get rave reviews every time I make this.  It's super easy to make, and I've never had anyone complain about the taste.  One modification I make is to pour the melted butter over the top and then sprinkle the cinnamon/sugar mixture on top of that (instead of mixing the butter with the cinnamon and sugar first).  This distributes the cinnamon/sugar more evenly.

Other commenters were not exaggerating about how good this recipe is. You know what croissant dough tastes like, and you know what cream cheese, sugar, cinnamon, and butter taste like, so you kind of expect it to taste like those things. I halved the recipe (sadly!) and reduced the sugar though.

region:

country:
None
text:
Husband loved it!  I didn't eat it because i'm gluten free.  I did follow others suggestions of cutting the sugar on top to 1/2 cup and also found that I needed much less butter.  I just melted the butter, brushed it on top then spread the cinnamon sugar on top.  
Also the crescent rolls?  I didn't need to roll out at all.  Just take straight from package and roll out on top of cooking pan.  Then you just have to do a little pinching together.  
Hubby said it tasted like cinnamon toast with cream cheese.  Went back for seconds!

text:
Great recipe!  A huge hit at my Cinco de Mayo party, and several recipe requests. After reading the reviews, I made a few changes .  . . I used three 8 oz packages of cream cheese, plus brushing the top layer with  2 Tbs softened butter then sprinkling the sugar/cinnamon on top of that. No pooling of butter like some cooks mentioned. The next time I will also pre-bake the bottom layer for a few minutes before adding the filling. It wasnâ€™t bad without pre-baking but I think it might help give the bottom a little more presence. I didnâ€™t even taste it without chilling . . . Trusted the other reviewers and waited until the next day to try and I was thrilled.

text:
This is a really easy recipe to use up older cream cheese. I cut the recipe in half, and even though I had less than 8oz of cream cheese, the inner filling was still thick. My only suggestion would be to reduce the butter portion of the topping  by maybe 1/8 cup so that you don't have too much runoff. The dessert was sweet enough without using any honey. This is definitely a keeper.

Made this for my momâ€™s birthday and it was a big hit. Easy to make and it turned out crunchy and sweet and cream cheesy. text:
This is SO good and is super easy to make!  I brought this to a family gathering and everyone was going back for seconds and thirds.  I cut mine into 24 pieces since it's so rich.   Everyone was surprised that there was Pillsbury biscuit dough in it. It tastes like a much more labor-intensive dessert.  When removing from the oven, I did push down slightly on the areas that had puffed up higher, because the honey was pooling in some areas. That helps the top get an even coating of the honey.

text:
I am the type that has to play with the recipe, so I made three, first i stiffen the cream cheese mixture with two egg yolks, and added 2 tablespoons of nutmeg. Then for the first one I added cherry pie filling between the cream cheese and the top crust, the second one I added frozen peaches in white sugar and lemon juice again between the cream cheese and the top crust, and the third one I added fresh black berries in brown sugar, corn starch, butter, and balsamic vinegar again between the cream cheese and the top crust, cooked them all off and all of them turned out amazing.

text:
I have made this multiple times through out the years. It pairs perfectly with Cafe Rio Chicken / Pork , black beans,  and cilantro-lime rice. A trick that I've learned when rolling out the crescent rolls is to forego unrolling them into triangles, but roll them into one solid square from the cylinder shape that they come out of the can.  This helps the shape to be solid and more unified.

text:
I made this in a half sheet pan for a graduation party. I used 5 cans of rolls, 6 pkgs of cream cheese, 3 cups of sugar and 3 tsp of vanilla. I tripled the topping ingredients but didn't use quite all of the butter mixture and freehand drizzled the honey. I added about 6 minutes to the cooking time to make sure the middle finished cooking.
It was great and there was the right amount of filling. After cooling, it came out of the pan easily. The leftovers made great snacks and breakfast.

text:
Yum!! I brought this to a weekly group where we always have snacks, and multiple people said it was it was the best snack we'd ever had. The only real change I made was I used regular vanilla instead of Mexican and doubled the amount. It was delicious -- the only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is because I wasn't a fan of how soggy the bottom crust was. Next time I would try pre-baking the bottom before assembling the rest of it. I did also get some excessive butter pooled on the top that I spooned off before it cooled off, but it was fine. So easy, too! I didn't use a rolling pin for the crescent rolls and I honestly don't know why you would because they were already a little longer than the pan as it was; it's not like they needed to be stretched out. Will definitely make again.

text:
warning:  If you take one bite, you will be addicted, and need to lock it up and throw away the key due to being  tempted to eat the whole pan in one  sitting.   This is without a doubt, one of the best-testing desserts ever.  I took this to a work function and everyone raved and raved.  I felt so silly taking compliments for something that was a snap to prepare.  I did use 4 oz more of cream cheese because I had some I wanted to use up, yet kept the sugar amt the same in the filling.  I'm glad that I did use that extra 4 oz, as the filling was just right; not too thick and not too thin.  I did decrease the amt of sugar in the topping to half a cup and it was plenty.  drizzled it w/honey.   I can't decide which was the best part; the filling or the slightly crunchy topping.  I see so many possibilities with this dessert; maybe a can of cherry pie filling, fresh blueberries, or adding lemon zest or mini chips to the cream cheese filling?   what a great recipe to tinker with.  I would suggest if you are making this to take to a big function, you make two pans.  This will be the first dessert to vanish.  thanks so much for this recipe.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2018-03-02T18:58:32.49
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
9132719
Display Name:
BonnieJo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/836828.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as written and it's good, but a little heavy on the butter and definitely too much sugar.  I think I'll try it again and reduce the sugar in the cream cheese mixture to 3/4 cup and cut the topping ingredients in half.  When mine came out of the oven, it had pools of butter which eventually soaked in, but I think it'd be better if you didn't use so much.  Don't cut back on the honey though.  The honey is fine as is.  Also, 30 minutes is not enough baking time.  Increase it to 40-45. It'll be browned on top, but that's better than mushy in the middle.

text:
I followed a few tips. Added 1 tsp of cornstarch, increased to 16 ozâ€™s of cream cheese, and baked the first layer of dough for 7 minutes. I just wasnâ€™t willing to risk having gooey dough. I let the dough completely cool prior to adding the filling. I did have to spread the cinnamon and sugar around while it was melting. I originally put about 8 dollops of the butter cinnamon and sugar mixture and it made little pockets where it was sitting. I would suggest to mix it up as the recipe states but put several little dollops on the top. Then maybe it will spread on its own. If not, make sure to check on it about 10 minutes in and spread it around. I also added 10 minutes to the timer. Still looked gooey on top in the center. It looks perfect and Iâ€™m excited to taste it for thanksgiving tomorrow! If the site allows me, Iâ€™ll update later on the taste but it looks exceptional and my house smells amazing! The kids are coming out of their rooms sniffing and smiling.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found this to be a relatively easy dish to make with the use of the crescent rolls. I don't use them often, but it was worthwhile in this case.I found the crescent roll dough easier to work with after unrolling it and sticking it in the pan, and the freezer about 15 minutes, the top layer I put in freezer an a cutting board. I reduced the sugar by approx. 30% and increased the cinnamon in the topping. Baked about 20 minutes, and added sliced almonds to the topping. I had to cook my dish about 10-12 minutes longer to obtain the browned pastry look. Cooled and refrigerated over night before cutting. Enjoyed by all!

country:
None
text:
SO simple to make but the results are great. I added about 3/4 of the amount of sugar in the filling and about 2/3 of the suggested sugar for the topping. Any more than this would have been far too sweet, and I also didn't bother with the honey. I also used less butter,  and brushed this on separately before the cinnamon sugar mix which I sprinkled on last.  I'd say the oven timings were just about right but my dish was slightly smaller than suggested and so I used a little less mix. If using the full amount I could see how you would need to cook it for longer. I left this to cool completely before eating which I'd recommend as it was easier to slice.

Display Name:
RV Living

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6970464.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Reduced the recipe to 4 servings and used 8 oz of cream cheese and 1 can of crescent rolls.  The dough for 4 rolls covered a 9"x9" metal baking pan.  

Used Splenda 1 for 1. The bag  states baked goods cook faster with Splenda than regular sugar.  20 minutes at 350 in a convection oven was PERFECT.

Topping: cut the Splenda and cinnamon into 3 TBS of butter and spread that over the top layer.  Sprinkled a little more cinnamon on top.  The texture of the topping baked out very nicely as if it was real sugar - like cinnamon toast.  I thought it would melt away along with the butter.  I doubt anyone could tell this is made with Splenda.

This was a nice treat for my diabetic hubs.  Still got 12 small portions and this is so rich even with a glass of milk, 2 small squares was enough.

This is going to be the new potluck recipe.  Thank you CandelB.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-08-29T17:39:55.3

region:

country:

text:
This was amazing.  Everyone loved it, and they've requested it be my "go-to" bring for potlucks at work.  I changed it up just a bit, although I'm sure it would be just as delicious as originally written.  I was feeding quite a few people, so I wanted a bit more volume in the cheesecake layer and added an extra block of cream cheese, an extra 1/4 C of sugar and an egg.  I also didn't use quite all of the cinnamon/sugar/butter topping, leaving probably a quarter of it in the dish.  I did spoon off a bit of butter that had pooled but not much at all and since the mixture gives it that slightly struesel top, I didn't want to remove much.  Oh!  I also added just a few pinches of cinnamon and sugar to the bottom crust before topping it with the cheesecake mix.  

Thanks for a crowd pleaser!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-08-15T14:51:49.377
helpfulCount:
0

FANTASTIC
This was excellent, easy and affordable. I made a half recipe in a glass pan and baked it for 35 minutes. I'm making it again and this time I'm using puff pastry. Delicious !
UPDATE 10/2/2017
I'm making this for the third time a half a recipe at a time. This time I used 1/2 cup of raspberry jam - stir it first or it won't spread well - and spread it on top of the cream cheese layer. Bake fir 35 minutes.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Super easy and turned out PERFECT!!   I followed the recipe exactly.  Don't worry about rolling out the bottom layer exactly to size ... just adjust it in the pan.  The second layer of crescent crust on top is the trickiest part.  Don't sweat it ... just put it on top and adjust .. it is impossible to mess this up.  And, I'm glad I watched the video because it demonstrated how to use the rolling pin to transfer the crust from the mat to the pan.    I did mess up the topping as I had to soften the butter in the microwave and it was more melted than I wanted.  This resulted in me spreading the cinnamon sugar mixture on the top crust versus dotting it.   I put it in the oven and pulled it when the timer went off.  Everyone loved it.

userID:
3347091
Display Name:
Moki Smudgemuffin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/286084.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this sopapilla cheesecake for Cinco de Mayo at work, and it was a big hit.  I made it twice, the first time as a test almost exactly by the recipe, with the only exception being that I used just 2-3 T butter and brushed it on the dough surface before adding the cinnamon-sugar topping.  So I used less butter, because I read over and over in the reviews that the quantity of butter called for was too much.  The second time I did the butter the same as the first, but there were a couple more alterations.  My alterations the second time were to use 3 pkgs cream cheese, rather than two, plus a room temperature egg in the filling, which made the dish rise more.  
Both recipes were super good, but I think I prefer the second one best because it made a thicker dessert, which went farther. 
I think it's worth buying the crescent dough that comes in whole sheets, too, rather than the perforated sheets, as the whole sheets were a bit easier to handle.  Basically, the perforated sheets tore at least 4 or 5 times, while the whole sheet only tore once, and it was a small tear.  And if it tears, pinch it back together, it will be fine.  I did use Mexican vanilla that I bought at the nearby Latin grocery, but I didn't notice that it added any distinctive flavor to the dish.  I think regular vanilla would be fine.

Next time I want to try sprinkling sliced almonds over the top before baking!

text:
I made this for a large family gathering. It got RAVE reviews and was gone in a flash! The best thing about it, other than taste, is the simple and super quick prep time! You can afford to back the sugar (inside and out) off a bit...and you could cut the butter back if you want by a couple of TBS. Also, to make it even easier, pillsbury makes 'dough sheet' tubes...so no need to pinch the crescent seems together. It's just one big dough sheet. ??

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed the recipe exactly - but wanted to share a few things that I learned. 1. When I made this, I didn't spread the cheese to all edges of the dough. So, the crust actually bubbled up and was doughy on the ends.  2. Because of this, I cut into bite size pieces and threw out the edge pieces. 3. This is very sweet and rich, so small bite-sized pieces are perfect. 4. After the dessert cools, cut into pieces and then refrigerate for several hours. It takes so much better cold! 5. The honey makes this dessert simply delicious - somehow it seemed very reminiscent of a sopapilla.

text:
I first had this about three  years ago when a coworker brought it to a potluck.  I had to make a dessert tonight that would work for someone who doesn't eat chocolate and one that doesn't eat peanutbutter and remembered it and looked up the recipe.  I see making more of these in my future.  I kept the filling sugar the same but added an additional cream cheese.  I brushed it liberally with melted butter and sprinkled with cinnamon sugar (I made as much as the recipe called for, but didn't use quite all of it).  Baked for about 40 minutes and got great reviews.  I didn't find it too sweet at all, I thought it was pretty much perfect.  It was VERY easy to make and yielded good results.  we had a small potluck with three desserts and almost all of this was gone.

text:
Delicious Dessert! Every time with rave reviews from friends and family! 3 tips that I have found help out tremendously. 1) Pre-bake the bottom crust for 7 minutes before adding the filling. 2) Melt the butter and brush on the top crust (uses less butter and no "butter pools"). 3) Lessen the sugar in the topping to 1/2 cup or even less.

text:
I made it exactly as written and it was fabulous. I did find it difficult to roll out the crescent rolls, but I used a store brand, which I will NEVER do again. Use the Pillsbury crescents - even better, use the crescent dough that isn't perforated. It was a huge hit - served it for brunch, like a cheese Danish. Because it is very rich I cut the pieces small, but people kept coming back for more and even asked if they could take some home. It was a HUGE hit.

text:
Delicious and so easy! Followed the recipe exactly as written, though I did use the regular vanilla I had on hand. Also, I had to alter the cooking time. After thirty minutes the outside was very crisp but the middle was still raw dough. I put foil around the edges to keep it from burning and left it the over for about 10 more minutes, until the middle looked properly done. So glad I did! The edges weren't burnt at all..the crispy end pieces were just as good as the softer middle pieces! Will definitely be making this again.

userID:
2625463
Display Name:
Danielle Harshenin
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5202891.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this dessert, and I love how easy it is to make!! It is definitley better chilled, so making it ahead of time is advised. I WAY reduce the sugar content. As written it would be sickeningly sweet. Reduce the sugar in the cream cheese to 2/3 cup. For the topping: Melt 1/4 cup of butter in the microwave and evenly distribute it over the top. Mix together 1/4 cup of sugar and 2 tsp of cinnamon, sprinkly evenly over the butter. Omit the honey. With these changes, it is PLENTY sweet!! UPDATE: this is SO GOOD served warm with vanilla ice cream.

5

text:
OMG this is fantastic!  I've never rated any recipe but I made this tonight & everyone was eating it hot out of the oven. I did take other suggestions: I used 2 & 1/2 - 8 oz cream cheeses. I reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup. I also put the bottom rolls in the oven for 9 minutes, then spread the cream cheese mixture. I melted the butter for the top & mixed 1/2 cup sugar & cinnamon & brushed it on the top. It baked for 45 minutes. I'll definitely be making this again & again. Thank you!

This is great! I made it half with honey drizzled on top and half without & can't decide between the two. Both are amazing! Made for a potluck at work - got lots of rave reviews. Didn't use the honey on top though. I couldn't believe it tasted so good, when it uses canned crescent rolls... but there is no trace of that fake processed taste the rolls can have.

text:
I did not expect it to be such a hit. I made it to take to a party. My husband wasn't so sure about it the way it looked but then he tasted it and then said lets just keep it home for us to eat and not take it to the party :). We took it anyway and people could not stop eating it. Everybody devoured it. 
Based on many other comments I did reduce the sugar. I added a little over 3/4th cup for the cream cheese mixture and a little over 1/2 cup for the topping.  I didn't measure the honey but just drizzled some over the top to cover most parts lightly. It was fantabulous and just the right amount of sweet. Any more would've been too sweet. 
My husband was a little sad that there was nothing left to take back home.

text:
Very good. Did not like it much at room temp, but after being refrigerated overnight...fantastic. I mistakenly only used 3/4 cup sugar in the cheesecake mixture, but was still good. I will use the full cup next time. Also didn't have and couldn't find Mexican vanilla, so had to use regular. I'd like to try it with the Mexican vanilla though. I, like a few others, had a little pooling of the butter, so I left it in the oven a little longer. Most of the pools dissipated, but the few small areas that were left I actually found to be my favorite pieces after it was refrigerated.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We just ate a piece. It is extremely sweet. I would reduce all sugar by 1/2. And let it cool all the way down for the cream cheese to harden back up, or refrigerate it until cool.  It really is a wonderful easy recipe to make.  If you want more of a cheesecake feel to it - you could add a 3rd box of cream cheese.  Don't forget to spray pan with Pam spray. You don't have to cook the crust seperately do it exactly like the recipe. Cook for full 30 minutes. It will shock you because it comes out really soft and you think it's not completely cooked, but it is. Just let it cool down to harden up. Give it a try you'll be pleased. My family really like it!

I have been making this recipe for years for pot lucks. I have people request this dessert all the time. Changes I would suggest. Add 1 more package of cream cheese, 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla, 1/2 cup sugar and one more package of crescent roll so that you have two layers of this dessert. Enjoy!

This is the second time I'm making this. The only thing I changed, both times, was the amount of sugar. We're not fans of super sweet stuff so I only add 1/3 cup to the cream cheese mixture and 1/3 cup to the topping. Both times, my family devoured this tasty little cake. Yummalicious!!! Thanks so much for sharing this!

text:
I've made this multiple times and everyone lives and requests this. The only thing I do that other reviews recommend, is to increase the filling to 3 blocks cream cheese and 1 1/2 cups sugar. To fix the butter pooling that others commented on, I open oven 20 minutes in and using a spoon, re-distribute over top, which fixes it without removing it. Very yummy, and good even if you don't have honey.

text:
Sopapilla Cheesecake Pie--really good if seriously sweet and sugary is your desert goal. These were still rich, sweet and sugary and I substituted NeufchÃ¢tel for the cream cheese, and cut the sugar by 1/4 cup each time it is listed. I could have eaten the entire bowl of the cream cheese layer all by myself--but I didn't. In addition to the NeufchÃ¢tel and less sugar, i omitted the honey drizzle. Next time, I'm cutting the sugar just alittle more and melting the butter for more better coverage of the topping. I live at high altitude so the next time I will bake it at 375 degrees, my bottom layer was a tad doughy so I need a higher temp or a longer baking time. This is a gorgeous looking, yummy desert for any occasion.

text:
Learn from my fail: make sure your cheese filling is very smooth and spreadable.   Mine was still pretty cool when I attempted to spread it over the bottom dough, and it wouldn't spread.  It tore holes in the dough, so I had to gently press it into place with my hands.  The top layer of dough covered it, and you couldn't even tell in the finished product.  This got more positive feedback than just about anything I have ever made for the family, and that is high praise, because I went out on a limb when I served this.  Serving anything other than chocolate is taking your life in your own hands with our crowd!  I will be making this one again....with a well-softened filling, of course.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I love cheesecake so I figured these would fit the craving. They were pretty good and I would make them again. HOWEVER, they seemed to have a way too much butter because after I baked them the melted butter pooled on top of the crescent dough which was kinda gross. I did half the recipe and used a 8x8 pan, so maybe this was the root of the problem, but I find that hard to believe. After the bars cooled the butter soaked in. I don't mind a lot of butter in a recipe if it fits its purpose. I would probably use half the butter dotted on top next time.  You could probably get away with skipping it altogether and just sprinkling the top with cinnamon-sugar to save on calories.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-05-05T12:00:27.587
helpfulCount:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy and VERY popular! It's so popular I have a little laminated tag I put with it that lists the ingredients (for people with allergies, etc) and a QR code that links to the recipe! That way, if people want the recipe, they just scan the tag and away they go!

You can double this and make it in a half-sheet size cake pan if you're cooking for a crowd. I always use a bit more vanilla, cinnamon and honey than is called for and it's always a hit.

**HINT** use the crescent roll dough made for recipes that's uncut if you can get it. It makes this even easier. I sometimes have problems with the triangles coming apart on the regular dough.

text:
I think this is so tasty and pretty simple to make.  I had heard of a similar recipe, so what I did different was to mix only about 1/4 cup of sugar and the cinnamon and sprinkle on top of the final crescent roll layer.  I also put some sliced almonds on top of that for a nice crunch. Then I melted the butter(I used salted, but think I will try unsalted next time) and poured it over top; then in the oven to bake.  Very good--got rave reviews!

text:
Hubby loved this. it's delish, easy substitue if you're craving cheesecake, but don't want the fuss. It was a bit too sweet for my taste, though. I think I may omit the honey, or cut the sugar in half next time. Definitely doesn't need all that sugar plus honey. Also, I used regular vanilla extract and it was fine. I'm waiting for my new rolling pin to arrive in the mail, so I just stretched and pressed down the dough with my hands, and it turned out fine.

text:
Grown men in my office almost went to blows over this one.  I've never seen anything like it.  Seriously, one guy sneaked out 2 pieces and hid them for later.  Everyone wanted the recipe.  I wish I had made more.  I followed the recipe exactly, except I just drizzled the honey over the top when I took it out of the oven.  I'm guessing not near 1/4 cup.  Also, I had to cook it closer to 40 minutes to get the center to puff up.  OH, and I assembled the crescent rolls with the cream cheese the night before, and added the butter/sugar/cinnamon and cooked the next morning.  That worked well. DELISH!  Enjoy.

text:
I have made this recipe a few times and there is never any left over.  I even brought it to a potluck at which there were several other really schmancy baked items from some high-end boutique bakeries.  This stuff was still the biggest hit!  Note that I have tried it with low-fat crescent rolls and it tastes great, but I don't think the dough rolls as easily/thinly so I used a smaller dish.  Also, I don't add the honey.  I'm sure that would be delicious, but I think it is sweet enough without it.

userID:
11506424
Display Name:
Valeria
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
64
favoritesCount:
252
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1041281.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Attempt #1. After defrosting I had the cream cheese with absolutely changed consistence. It was not creamy, but watery and very grainy. Thus I didn't expect that I would cook anything great from it. Anyway I determined to bake sopapilla cheesecake. Here are those alternations I made to cook it: 1. I beat the defrost cream cheese very well in order to get rid of all these grains. It was in vain. It's just impossible to get rid of them completely. It does not matter. 2. Blended it with 1 cup (120 g) of powdered sugar, vanilla, 1 egg and 1/4 cup of cornstarch. . It was still very liquid. Whatever. 3. Poured this medley on the piece of flaky pastry put in 9x13 cake pan (just regular 1-2-3 pastry). I didn't cover my pie with another piece of flaky dough, cause the filling was very liquid due to this defrost cream cheese. So I put neither butter nor sugar over it. I just threw it into the oven for about 50 minutes. In the end I got the extremely delicious dessert, my dad said he had never eaten anythng better. No doubts it was not a true sopapilla cheesecake, but it was quite a good way to get rid of this cream cheese. Will do it again with fresh cream cheese.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I was looking for a mexican-style dessert and stumbled on this! I'm not a great cook, but this was super easy for me. Instead of rolling out the dough, I just pressed the edges of the crescent rolls together. This turned out perfectly without all the mess of rolling!

This recipe tastes amazing. I tried some when it was still a bit warm (couldn't wait!) and it tasted great! It gets even better when it's cold. I served it to my family, they don't particularly like cinnamon or honey, but they adored this cheese cake. Several friends have asked for the recipe.

All in all, this is very easy to make (even for amateurs) and tastes sooo good.

text:
Delicious!  I followed the recipe pretty closely, although I didn't bother to roll out the layers of crescent roll dough . . . I just pressed the seams together.  To save time, on the top layer of dough, I spread some Land O Lakes Light Butter and then sprinkled the cinnamon/sugar mixture on top of the butter (I didn't end up using all the cinnamon/sugar either, so I'll save that for next time).  I used 1/3 less fat cream cheese for the filling.  Next time I will halve the filling components just to lessen the calories some more.  This was also excellent as a cheese danish/pastry the next morning.  Great recipe!  Thanks!

I tasted this at a church potluck recently...when I saw the little squares on the table I wasn't really sure what they were, I actually thought it was some kind of bread pudding. Well, thank goodness I picked one up...one bite and I was AMAZED! I searched around asking who made this dessert, in dire need of the recipe! I couldn't believe when I heard it was made with just crescent rolls, cream cheese and a few more simple ingredients. This dessert tastes like it should have been complicated and taken a long time to make. I was thrilled to be told this recipe could be found on allrecipes and it was so simple. Thank you for sharing this amazing dessert with us! These little bites of cheesecake heaven make this world a better place...truly one of the best desserts I've ever tasted. It's perfectly cheesy and sweet, almost a mix between cheese danish and cheesecake. I can't say enough about this recipe...if anyone has never tried this just make it...now! region:

country:
None
text:
I have made it twice now and it is one of our families favorite recipes.  I took it to work and it was gone almost instantly!
I followed it true to the recipe and it was perfect.  Some reviews recommend 3 pkgs of cream cheese but I think it would be too much filling. But you MUST drizzle the honey as it adds such nice flavor.  I find it hard to find the crescent sheets BUT I did find a new crescent roll package (Pillsbury) that makes larger crescent rolls - it's a 12 oz package VS. an 8 oz and I will use that from now on as I like the added crust volume.  No need to roll out the dough, just pat the triangles into the pan - one can for the bottom and one for the top and with the larger size can just tear any of the extra dough into pieces and just randomly place it around on top of the dough layers.

received many compliments!
was able to found the crscent baking sheets so i lucked out there.
i prebaked the bottom crust for 8 mins in the oven and whipped the cream cheese mixture while that cooled.
changes i made: used 3 packs of cream cheese-could have got away with 2-2.5 i thought it was too much cream cheese. i also added 1 egg to the cream cheese mixture.
i brushed the butter on the top crust them sprinkled the cinnamon and sugar mixture all over. i didn't use it all bu ti think in the end it could have used a bit more. this recipe is a winner and it can def be tweaked depending on your tastes. everyone loved it will def make again

text:
Everyone LOVED this and its very easy.

I didn't make any changes to the ingredients - except I didn't have Mexican vanilla and used regular.

Its very rich and sweet so I think I cut this in about 24 or so pieces.

Its also much better refrigerated for awhile after it cools - and easier to cut.

I had to bake mine about 45 minutes.  At 30 minutes, there was still butter pooled on the top and it wasn't very browned.  A few more minutes browned it a little more and let the butter cook in.

text:
Oh my gosh!  I can't believe I waited so long to make this. My husband loved it and he is not a big fan of cheesecake.  I did reduce the sugar to 3/4C and also reduced the butter used for the top.  I also added an egg.  I know I should not rate the recipe before making it as written but I really don't think the recipe can be bad any way you make it. After making it, I found that 1/2 c of butter is too much. I reduced amount to 1/4c melted it and brushed it on top. Reduce the sugar to 1/2c and 1 tsp of cinnamon. Delicious!

My family LOVED this dessert!! I have made it a few times now and I have made some changes since there is way to much sugar in this recipe. I used 2/3 C sugar and added a little cinnamon to the cream cheese mixture. Also I melted 1/3 stick of butter and brush it on the the top. Then sprinkle 1/4 C cinnamon sugar mixture on top. I did make a pumpkin version as well which was a hit at Thanksgiving! I added 1/3 C pumpkin puree, 2 1/2 blocks cream cheese, and added allspice. The rest was the same as above. It was amazing!

None
text:
These are great as is, but I make a few changes. I bake on a Jelly Roll Pan. I don't roll out the dough, smashing it down with your hands gets it thin enough. It does not have to be perfect! Also, the drizzled honey makes this have more of a sopapilla flavor, however, I have noticed if you allow the honey to absorb you lose that flavor. It is less sticky/messy and retains flavor if you dip the warm pieces into the honey.

I was skeptical when I read reviews boasting heaven on a plate. As I served it to visiting family I thought "oh no, I never made this before. I shouldn't use them as guinea pigs!" Then, before I could sit down to my own piece, it was getting rave reviews. My bf's face LIT UP and he actually asked for 2nds! This coming from a man who doesn't really eat sweets and his idea of a brownie's serving sive (his fav sweet) is a square inch! I then took a bite and could practically see the pearly gates. LOVE LOVE LOVE this!! If i could give more stars, I would!

text:
I personally think it's a bit sweet but EVERYONE whose tried it LOVES it.  It is a hit everywhere I take it.  This is one of those dishes that has people asking for the recipe.  The recipe is easy to follow.  I now make it with a tad less sugar and cinnamon for the topping and it still works out fine, I sometimes omit the honey drizzle as well.  I sometimes have problems rolling out the cresent dough.  It's due to my lack of experience I'm sure.

This was wonderful!! I followed the recipe exactly. I also sprinkled some sliced almonds on top; they looked pretty. As ovens vary, I had to cook mine for 40 minutes (the middle was still a bit gooey after 30). It came out perfectly and was delicious both warm out of the oven and cold the next day. It is really sweet,  but really, really, really good. I printed the recipe out for my boyfriend's mother so she can make it for her skiing friends. She'll be a hit with this recipe!!

I made this tonight for the first time for a Mexican-themed potluck.  I thought that it was very good, and everyone else (especially my husband) thought it was delicious!  Super easy to make too! Rolling out the crescent rolls on wax paper was a great idea by another reviewer.  It took about 45 minutes to bake in my oven.  I served it at room temperature.

userID:

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So Easy and SUPER DELISH! I had to come up with something quick for a treat to take to a gathering. I had 2 tubes of crescent rolls and found this recipe. I was in a hurry so I didn't read the recipe super close, so I ended up making a few (accidental) changes. After layering the cream cheese, I topped it with cinnamon and sugar and a bit of honey. I then layered the top crescent roll and topped that with melted butter mixed with the sugar and cinnamon. I added the honey before baking. It took 30 minutes in my oven and it was fantastic! I doubt you could really screw this one up. My new quick "go to"! Everyone raved and wanted the recipe! Thanks for sharing!

text:
I was this for a Cinco De Mayo party at work.  It was a BIG hit with everyone asking for the recipe. I made it exactly as the recipe states (except I only had American? vanilla flavoring).  Almost skipped buying the honey but am glad I didn't.  It gave it that extra little umph!  Very Good!
